div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each shipâ€™s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Companyâ€™s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains is $9 to Brindisi. The combined Sea and speical train fare has been reduced to $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

While the world's press is making great captial out of the two days of distrubances at Tokio that followed the publication of the peace tready, the sence of incendiarian and frenzied slaughter at Baku a nd other great centres in Transcaucasia seem to have caused much less concern to the European Press. The “Morning Poet" hints that, owing to the recent disturbances, the Armenians of the Russian province have drawn the vengeance of the Krirds upon their heads, by refusing to pay the prescribed does to their Knrd and Tartar feudal superior, though this hardly explains the massacres of Armenian workmen at Shousha, Tiflis and Baku. We imagine that town-labourers, even in a Russian province, are not as a role subject to Moslem Seigneurs, and the explanation given by Beater and repeated by the Russian correspondents of the "Times,’’ vis., that the folly of the Russian Government which incited the Moslem population of these disturbed and semi-barbarous districts to assail the Armenians who had shown them selves sworn enemies of M. do Plehve’s policy of Rosmfiostion, is now being punished by these very Moslem allies,—is to us far more convincing. The economic consequences of the revolt are most grave. The less to the oilfields through the suspension of Hair output is estimated at nearly £50,000 a day. The damage done by the burning of the wells and destruction of factories and plant runs into millions. All the silk weaving establishments and spirit distilleries in certain districts have gone the way of the oil wells, and the mines and copper foundries are threatened. Factories in the Volga district are dosing right and left owing to the limitation of the output, and the losses sustained by British investors are described as being ruinous. The Government, after playing the part of a comatose spectator at a melodrama, has been suddenly galvanised into activity by the eruption of an army of Persian Kurds, whose operations are marked by the same inhumanity as were those of their cousins west of the Turkish border during the Armenian massacres. Prince Inuis Napolson Bonaparte, who is reputed, like many other Princes, to possess great military and adminis-trative talent has been appointed Governor- General of the whole disturbed territory. He will need some of the genius of his illustrious grand node to enable him to restore order and quiet in the distracted, province. Taming to Japan the news reoeived of the rioting in Tckio early in the month, and at Yokohama yesterday, is distressing enough reading to those who regard the Japanese as super human beings, but we imagine that bad the British Government called a halt after the surrender at Paardeburg and announced its intention of exacting no further reparation from the Boer Republic, there would have been an abundance of broken heads in Trafalgar Square and Hyde Park. That some of the Japanese rioters should have shown signs of an anti-foreign feeling is notamasing. not amazing. Despite the pacific protests of European Governments, the Japanese know perfectly well that had they not abolished their semi-feudal system, put an end to their exclusive policy, and, above all armed themselves on land and sea, they would sooner or later have pursade China, and seen spheres of influenced established near all their best harbours. They know that Europe only commenced to respect them when they showed that their fleet could manoeuvre, and their army storm entrenched positions, and that to the avenge American or European “hustler" the artistic merits of the Japanese, their politeness, good taste and public spirit, were regarded at beet with the admiration people expend on ancient brio-a-brac which they have no intention of baying. The attitude of the Japanese Government has, however, m most correct since the revolution that abolished the Shogunate, and the self-respect and discipline of the nation, regarded as a whole, cannot be said to be impaired by the riotous conduct of a few thousand rowdies in the capital and at the most occidentalised of the Treaty Ports.

div.head: NORWAY AND SWEDEN
div.p: RELATIONS STRAINED.
MUTUAL ACCUSATIONS

STOCKHOLM, September 14. The feeling in Norway and Sweden is apparently again most strained. An author¬itative announcement here accuses Norway of wilfully deceiving the foreign press on the subject of tho demolition of frontier fortifica¬tions, while Norwegians declare that Sweden is now making conditions harder than those decided upon by the Rigsdag. Yesterday a Stockholm paper alleged that the Norwegian reserves have been mobilised on the frontier. This is denied at Christiania. (Reuter

div.head: BAKU OIL INDUSTRY.
div.p: PROTECTIVE PRECAUTIONS.

BAKU, September 14. The oil producers have sent a memorial to tie Minister of finance pointing out the help- issuess of the police to guard the oil-fields, nd declaring that they have decided to pay be banditti an enormous sum monthly as a ransom for the safety of life and property. (B.)
BAKU, September 14. The disorders continue. The English and a jw other firms began to repair, but the threats f the revolutionaries compelled them to desist. ( Reuter

div.head: THE CALABRIAN EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: THE SHOCKS CONTINUE.
ROME, September 14. King Victor Emmannel is still visiting the villages in the region devastated by the earth- ake personally comforting the inhabitants, ere have been fresh shocks to-day. (Reuter)

div.head: YOKOHAMA PEACE RIOTS
div.p: TROOPS SENT FROM TOKIO.
YOKOHAMA, September 14. Serious anti-peace rioting took place here yesterday. The mob destroyed and burned 11 police kiosks. Troops sent from Tokio are guarding the consulates and warehouses. (B.)

div.head: FINLAND POLITICAL SITUATION
div.p: MEETING DISPERSED BY MILITARY.

HELSINGFORS, September 14. 800 delegates from all the towns in Finland met here to discuss the political situation The police order to break up was ignored whereupon the military was summoned and dispersed the meeting with fixed bayonets. (R)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in Helonan during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 17th inst. will be poisoned by the police.
A BOY MISSING.—It is reported from the Labban kism that a hoy called Yousef Turk, eleven years of age, has been missing from home two days
A PLAGUE CORDON.—The sanitary authori- , ties have ordered a cordon to be drawn round the house of Ahmed Mustapha in Karmous kism where there has been a case of plague.
A WOMAN STABBED —The police have ar¬rested two Turks in the Labban quarter for j having stabbed a woman named Malaka bint Mustapha in the chest. The woman has been removed to hospital.

SUEZ CANAL. 9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 12th irst., 7 of which were British, 1 German. 1 Dutch. The receipts for the day were frs. 268,834.36, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 3,462,139.87.

SOCIETE DU TIR AU PIGEON —We are asked to state that this club will hold meetings at Gabbari at 3 p.m. to morrow snd at 9 a.m. on Sunday, when the championship for the year 1905 will be shot for by the best shooters of Cairo and Alexandria The first prize will be 2,000 francs, and there will also ba gold and silver medals and other prizes given sway. At 3 p.m. on Sunday there will be a shooting match between Cairo and Alexandria.

LEAP FOR LIBERTY.—A criminal who was being sent by train from Mansonra to Zagazig under the charge of a policeman, jumped out of the carriage window a few miles short of the latter town, before the train slackened speed. The policeman followed suit, but falling heavi¬ly, broke one of bis ribs. The criminal escaped uninjured from his leap, but was overtaken by some natives who were passing near the rail¬way at the time. The policeman has been removed to hospital

MAGIC AND SPELLS.—A certain Sayed Ahmed of El Azarito, Moharrero Bey Kism. informed the police yesterday, that ho recently entrust¬ed £50 to three wizards from Morocoo, who promised to make the fifty sovereigns into eighty by means of various incantations, after the manner of the renowned John Wellington Wells. Sayed Ahmed now complains that he has set eyes neither on the money and on the magicians since he entrusted his earnings to their care. We doubt if he will see either again.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.—We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer¬chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint¬ing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of ail British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of£l. The latter payment aho includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

THE CALABRIAN EARTHQUAKE. — A special committee in Cairo is about to he formed to organise a theatrical performance, the proceeds of which will be devoted to the victims of the Calabrian earthquake, and which we under-stand, will be held at the Khedivial Opera House. The management of the Mex Casino, Alex¬andria, announces a "grand festival,” consisting of a vocal concert,the second part of the Italian drama. VXIX Luglin^nA the Spanish zarzuela La Gran Via, for Sunday next from 4 to 8 p.m. in aid of the sufferers, and, as we have previously announced, the Della Guardia Dra-matic Company will give a benefit performance on Monday evening. Private subscriptions are also freely flowing in, the latest being the munificeut donation of 3,000 francs from MM Raphael and Felix Soares. Egypt is certainly responding nobly to the appeal for her aid, and we feel sure that all those who do not find themselves able to give subscriptions to the funds will swell them by buying tickets for some of the many theatrical efforts

div.head: SUCRERIES D’EGYPT.
div.p: of the Credit Mobilier is announced. The capital of the new bank is fixed at twelve and a half million franos. Sir Ernest Cassel is interested in its promotion, which has for its object the consolidation and reconstruction of the Societe de Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d’Egyptc. Two of the directors of this society left yesterday for Egypt in order to attend the extraordinary meeting which is to be held in Cairo, and were accompanied by two chartered accountants. A meeting of the shareholders in France of the Sucreries was held yesterday at Paris, when a committee was appointed to protect their interests.

A telegram which arrived after we had gone to press contradicts the statement that Sir Ernest Cassel is connected with the Franco- Egyptian bank mentioned above and that the bank is interested in the reconstruction of the Socidtd des Sucreries d’Egypte.

div.head: THE CHATHAM DISASTER.
div.p: (FROM OUR PORT SAID CORRESPONDENT.) (By Telegraph.)

Friday, noon. The commission which has been appointed by the board of the Suez Canal Company to enquire into the Chatham accident, and to consider the beet means by which the danger from the cases of dynamite to other ships may be averted, and also the vessel refloated, will arrive here on Wednesday. 1 do not think that there is any likelihood that such strong measures as the blowing up of the Chatham will have to be undertakes. At present all traffic in the canal is stopped, and a number of vessels are waiting to enter both at Port Said and Suez.

div.head: RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: At a late hour last night four trucks of a goods train left the rails near Kafr Davar, owing, as far as is known, to the breaking of a wheel. The last four vans of the train were derailed but the damage done was not very considerable. Traffic was of course impeded, the sleeping-oar train which leaves Cairo at 11.15 p.m. being an hour and twenty minutes late in arrival at Alexandria, and the early postal deliveries in the towns of Cairo and Alexandria, as well as the top country mails were greatly retarded.
The railway authorities did all in their power to clear the line, a break down train coming from Alexandria under the charge of Mr. Hilpern and the men taking up the work as soon as they arrived.

The railway officials showed great considera-tion for the first-class passengers in the sleep¬ing car train, in not waking them till the relief train had arrived at the scene of the accident, and but little inconvenience was experienced. It was not until six o’clook that the passengers were awakened by the request to change trains, so that they had their allotted time of sleep, the train being due at Alexandria 'at 6 a.m.

div.head: ATTACKS ON BRITISH DH0WS.
div.p: Telegraphing from Constantinople under date of the 6th inst Reuter’s Correspondent states that serious complaints have recently ' been made by the British Embassy to the Porte ' on the subject of the repetition of piratical attacks upon British dhows in the Red Sea and at other parts of the Arabian coasts. If the Ottoman Government is unable to take effectual measures to prevent these out¬rages, it may be necessary for the British government to punish the offenders, and exact reparation themselves.

We mentioned some time ago that Mr. Parvis, a Cairo engineer, had been had been authorised by the Italian Government to subMIT a detailed project, with plans, for the construction of a new building to house the four Dalian schools in the capital that receive a Government subsidy. This building is to be erected on the site, purchased some three years ago from the local author- ities, situated in the Bonlac road, near the j projected

div.head: ITALIAN SCHOOLS
div.p: new Boulevard Abbas. The ground was sold by the Ezyptian Government at a nominal price, a few piastres per square metre, and the cost of the new buildings will probably amount to about 500,000 francs, for which sum it is expected very handsome and commodious premises will be provided. As soon as the necessary authorisation is received . from Rome, the Consulate in Cairo will invite tenders for the construction of the buildings, which will take at least six months to com¬plete,and will he the finest of their kind in the j Metropolis.

div.head: THE LATE S FELICE.
div.p: Madame Salvatore Felice, the parents and relations, invite their friends and acquaint¬ances to attend the funeral rites of the late Signor Salvatoro Felice, vice Consul at Zags zig. who died at Vienna on the 2nd inst. The funeral precession will leave St Catherine’s Church on Monday next at 5 o’clock in the afternoon. No other intimation will be given, and all are begged to consider the present as M invitation to attend. -fi-l NOTE BY MR. WEBB.

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: The flood is, no doubt, bad, being one metre below the average ; although the actual areaIn my Note of the 20th ult it was stated that the condition of the irrigation of the basin lands was far from favorable, that an im¬mediate improvement would take place, owing to the rise which had occurred on the Blue Nile and Atbara on the 10th alt, and that a second rise on the 20th ult would probably result in maintaining the levels of the river during September. The following tables show that this forecast was correct, and that, though considerably later than usual, the flood of this year will be scarcaly inferior to that of last year, which was low, but superior to those of 1902 and 1899, which were very low.

. AT KHARTOUMunirrigated in the basins may be the same as last year, still the irrigation of a much larger area is unsatisfactory, and the out-turn must be much less than on land which has been thoroughly soaked by the flood. The Barrages.—Regulation on the Delta, Zifta and Assiout Barrages still continues. Perennial Irrigation. - Except in a very few places, the flood crops have all been sown. Conditions have been quite favorable. Basin Irrigation. - The filling of the basics is progressing as well as the levels will allow : if the river levels are maintained fairly constant daring September a large area, now unirrigated, will be covered during the "sarf” operations, so that the probable area of sharaki should not exceed 50,000 feddans, though a much greater area will be very inadequately irrigated.

div.head: FAYOUM AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).

Fayoum, Thursday. After leaving Alexandria on behalf of the “Egyptian Gazette” to attend the Agricul¬tural Show, I arrived at Medinet-el-Fayoam to find the station decorated and the streets leading from it to the exhibition hung with banting. Stands had been erected in reveral places and the general effect was most pio- turesque. On entering the exhibition, my fiat impression was that I was admiring the Cairo Agricultural Show. The excellent ar¬rangements and the division of the exhibits in various sections had obviously been modelled on the procedure so successfully followed by the Khedivial Agricultural Society. The exhibits—cotton,fruit,cereals, live-stock, poultry, etc. were all grouped and classed in a thoroughly up-to-date manner,and the organ-isers of the exhibition deserve the greatest credit for their success. The exhibits of hones, camels, mules and sheep were greatly admired, and among the last class was a most remark¬able animal, a four-horned sheep from Tobhar village, with four perfect horns, like that men-tioned by St. John in Holy Writ (Surely the allegorical Lamb of St John’s Apocalypse had seven horns. Ed.KG.) The exhibits of fresh olives, lemons, and other fruits were very good. Among the poultry some very fine turkeys of a pure snow white colour were particularly admired, while of the other exhibits I must not omit to mention the numerous stuffs and fabrics man¬ufactured in Egypt among which the woollen robes and shawls of the Bedouin, rugs, mate, fellaheen cloaks, and silken robes were most pleasing to the eye, while a beautiful and tasteful Syrian silk dress, the old customes of that country, would have delighted any Euro¬pean lady of taste. The show was officially opened to-day by Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, uncle of H.H. the Khedive. Among those present I noticed H.H. Prince Omar Pasha Touasoun, Mr. Foaden, Mr. Goldie, M. de Hilbert, Mr. Branch, Mr. Jelly, Mr. Boxwell, Mr. Goodchild,

div.head: NOTES FROM FAYOUM.
div.p: Mr. Rule, Abaza Pasha, Abdul Hamid Bey Abaza, Chawarbi Pasha, Haroun Pasha, Said Pasha, Mahmoud Bey Yeghen, Shahin Pasha, Tomoun Bey, Toulba Bey Sioudi and many notables, sheikhs, and omdeha from Upper and Lower Ejypt. All were delighted with the exhibition, and special thanks are due to Mr. G. Foaden and his capable assistants, who played a great part in the work of arrange¬ment and organisation. MR WAY AND THE S.P.C.A. Mr. Way, inspector of the Agricultural Bank at Fayoum leaves to day for Ghizeh where he will stay for two months. I should like to take this oppurtunity of testifying to Mr. Way’s business ability and to his popularity in the district Since July last, Mr. Way has been acting as secretary of the S.P.U. A. branch here, daring which time he enlisted no less than sixty new native subscribers of all classes, and has received donations amounting to over £100. Mr. Way has bought a plot of ground on which the S.P.C.A. have erected a hospital for sick animals. Till to-day 115 animals have been treated there, eighty two donkeys, twenty three horses and ten mules, a most excellent start in my opinion.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: JULLIOT BEY. The late Julliot Bey, whose death wee re¬cently reported from Marseilles, first visited Egypt as manager of the sugar factory at Abu-Kourgas. He was well known and greatly respected by the French colony of Cairo. His knowledge of his profession was remask- able and his seal and honesty universally re¬cognised. The deceased, bad to leave Egypt consequence

div.head: Sucreries et Rafflnerie d’Egypte
div.p: Une banque frauco-dgyptienne est fonddo par une socidtd anglaise sous lea auspices du Crddit Mobilier. La capital de la uouvelle banque est fixd k douze millions et demi de francs. Sir Ernest Cassel est intdressd k son lanoement qui a. pour but la consolidation et la reconstitution de la Socidtd de3 Suoreries et Raffinerie d’Egypte. Deux des administra- teurs de oette sooidtd, acoompagnds de deux oomptables assermentds, sont partis bier pour l’Egypte en vue d’assister k l’Assemblde extra-ordinaire qui aura lieu au Cairo. Hier a eu lieu k Paris une assemble des aotionnaires des Sucreries au oonrs de laquelle a dtd nommd un oomitd de defense*- des intdrdts des porteurs irangais. L’usine de Rodah est fsrmde; celle de Bibeh le sera dgalement; k Nag Hamadi, on compte travailler encore, mais partout un grand nom bre d’employds sont licencies. Le bilan de la Socidtd sera ddposd samedi proohain au greffe commercial du Tribunal mixte du Cairo, soit trois jours avant l’au dience fixds, pour statuer sur l’admission de la Socidtd k bdndfioier du oonoordat prdventif.

div.head: ISLAND OF CYPRUS.
div.p: MOUNT TROODOS.
(FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)

But the Anglo-Egyptian tourist to Cyprus will especially want to know about the drive from Limasol to Troodos, the summer hill station of the island, what are the excursions to be taken from there, and what sort of accommodation is to be expected. In the first place the site of the now hotel is over 5,000 feet above the sea, the summit of Olympus being an hoar’s walk therefrom, at a height of 6,500 feat, so that the nights are colder than any other place in the Levant, and the traveller must go armed with cloak and rugs and warm under the rugs, or else the sudden drop of temperature in the afternoons will cause a chill. The military and civilians do not go up until after the middle of June, and it is impossible to live there before that date, bnt the weather beoomes much warmer in July and August, and daring that time it is a most invigorating and delightful change from the flats of Egypt. There are new two roads up to the soldiers’ camp, and the tents and huts of the English residents in the island ; they do not separate for the first eighteen miles, but after that the older road descends into a narrow, airless valley to cross the mountain torrent below, and then ascends again by many bare and chalky zigzags which are most unpleasantly glaring in the heat of the day. It is not until Peripedio, with its clumps of magnificent old trees, is reached that the road is of any real beauty. The enterprising traveller will here hire either male or mountain pony, and ride through the pass of Peripedia, where some fine rook and water soenery is to be found, all of which is missed by the circuitous road. The bridal path ends in a steep ascent through some vine groves which brings one to Platras (3,000 feet) where accomodation can be had far the night. The rest of the journey is lovely, but the climb is very steep for the horses ; past rush- ing streams, and the beautiful foliage around the Caledonian falls, leaving the Government offices on the left and Government house on the right as yon wind in and out up the valley, till at length the khan is reached 5,000 feet about the sea. By this route the journey takes above twelve hours. But undoubtedly the new road is the more beautiful as well as the more gradual ascent of the two. The first three miles might be con¬siderable shortened if the Government only had enough money to make several bridges to span the months of some of the narrow gullies, instead of winding in and out every time. But after passing some artless clusters of myrtles and olives, oleanders and vines, pome granates and figs, all growing side by side, in a watered dyke, the road enters a long and winding valley of singular freshness and interest. Were it within the borders of the United Kingdom it would before now be world-renowned and stocked with ohar-a-bancs every day. First of all, the change in the flora and vegetation is wonderful. Whereas the carob and olive trees divide the honors from the coast to 2,000 feet, the carob then ceases to grow and the olives cling to the sheltered valleys op to 9,500 feet, looking more and more piteons in the colder air. Meantime tie vines begin to spread over every sunny slope and open reach, up to 4,000 feet. As soon as the olivos have disappeared, the walnuts take their place, and the Syrian firs and pines begin to grow in abundance. At the end of Jane bracken was growing everywhere, aud honey¬suckle was in full bloom, with all sorts of mountain flowers as well The smell of sage and thyme was fragrant, and this when added to the scent of the pines filled the air with perfume. At the end of the valley the road begins a long series of zigzags, but by this way there are ever-changing moun¬tain views, and lovely peeps into the valley be¬low. And so long as there have been no serious rains upon the hills steady progress can be made. But the road becomes very heavy in places even after a passing storm, especially after the road from Nicosia is met, upon a shoulder in the ridge from which a beautiful new is gained of the central plain be¬low and the northern range beyond. About an hour and a half out of camp, an ioy-oold fountain is reached, which was enclosed in 1900—the year that the road was made. Above it reads this suitable inscription from Holy Writ. ‘‘He sendeth his springs into the rivers which run among the hills,” and it was a pleasure to see this recognition of Almighty Cod. The camp on Troodos is situated on one of the projecting spurs of the range known as “the hogs” back.” The mountain paths are all of a red colour, and are both soft to the tread and picturesque to look at. The pines on the summit of the range are Scotch, and not Syrian pines, being only found in the Levant on this high range. They grow almost to the very summit of the mountain, where they are displaced by scrub and the plantagenista which I found right at the crest of the mountain-top. Accomodation can be had at the hotel for about 7/ a day, and animals can be hired at the khan close by for excursions. KYKKON MONASTERY. The ride to Kykkon is the most picturesque of all, bat this involves a night out at the hospi¬table Greek Monastery of Kykkon, which is very clean and well worthy of a visit. The monks are quite accustomed to visitors, bat as none of them know any language but Greek, except their cultivated Abbot, who is only resident in August, I believe, daring the summer, it is best to take a dragoman. The way, too, it by no means easy to find, and even travellers with guides have often gone far out of their way. The route can be varied during the middle part of the course, so as to take in the “village of cherries.” Is there another valley of such cherry trees to be found elsewhere. Let the reader go and decide the matter for himself. The beginning of July is the proper season for a visit. These cherries are export-ed to Port Said and Alexandria every Friday by the mail boat, but they arrive in Egypt in a very different state from when gathered from the trees ! There are many other excursions, both short and longs for riders and pedestrians, that can be taken, not the least of which includes the visit to the snow-pits on Olympus, and the view from the top on a dear day, of the sea in many different directions, with magnificent and pano- ramioland views , but enough I trust has been written to induce some of my compatriots to visit Cyprus another year, and to help forward the mutual friendship and interest of both countries in the days to comp. I may add, by the way, that no quarantine was imposed upon any English people, to my knowledge, who visited Cyprus during this summer, whereas others who essayed to enter Syria had to suffer the discomforts of the lazaretto which some of us know too well.

div.head: STARTING OF STEAM-TURBINES.
div.p: If a large steam-turbine is cold and at rest, how quickly can it be started ? Can it be brought up to speed as readily as can a good cross-compound engine that is cold all over We have taken the time in a nnmbar of in¬stances when all the auxiliaries have been in motion, and it only remained to start the turbine and phase it in on the line: the only valves to open in such cases are the throttle and one small oil-valve. The two quickest starts have been made in 45 seconds and 70 seconds respectively, including phasing-in. Others range between 1 minute 10 seconds and 1 j minute. These two quickest starts were made on a turbine which had stood for 24 hours with the throttle-valve shut tight, though there was a slight leakage past the seat After the throttle-valve is off its seat, it is not more than 30 seconds before the turbine is np to speed. A cross-compound reciprocating engine of the four-valve type, 2,250 horse power ca¬pacity, can be brought up to speed from a standstill in 5 minutes if it is hot all over. This 5 minutes is to be compared with the 70 seconds required for the similar turbine opera¬tion. A reciprocating engine which is turning over slowly, with the throttle-valve just off its seat, or with by-pass open and having all its oil-cups open and regulated, can be brought up to speed, say seventy-five revolutions in two minutes. This can be compared with the thirty secouds necessary for bringing the turbine up ! under the same conditions—that is, about one- i fifth the time necessary for bringing up the engine. If the engine is cold all over, and has all its oil-cups shut tight, all its auxiliaries quiet, fifteen minutes is called a rapid start. Starts have been made under such conditions in twelve minutes. When we start a cold turbine, we open up the valve and let her turn, and in two minutes wo are ready to bring her up to speed, and she will be at speed in 2 minutes, one-fourth the engine’s time. “Engineering.”

div.p: CESARE GIANNI, DECEASED.

PURSUANT to Act of Parliament 22-23, Yio\, Cap. 35, Notice is hereby given that all creditors find other persons having any claims or demands against the Estate of OESARE GIANNI, late of Pension Forio, Rue Cherif Pasha, Alexandria (who died on the 14th day ol November, 1904, at Pension Forio aforesaid, intestate, and to whose Estate Letters of Administration were on the 16th day of May, 1905, granted by His Majesty’s High Court of Justice at the Principal Probate Registry in England, to CARMEN GIANNI, the lawful widow and relict of the said deceased, and of which letters of administration a copy has teen produced at, and deposited with, the Cairo District Registry of His Britannic Majesty’s Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte), are required to send particulars of their claims to the under¬signed within thirty days from the date here-under after which the said Administratrix will proceed to distribute the assets of the said deceased among the parties entitled thereto, having regard only to such claims of which she shall then have had notice ; and she will not be liable for the assets so distribute d to any person of whose claim she shall not then have had notice Dated, Cairo, this 14th day of September, 1905. For the Administratrix, EM. SGIORTINO, 864301 Advooeto, Cairo.
